matter_title: Investing and Strengthening Social Emotional Learning Competencies and Practices Across Los Angeles Unified for College, Career and Beyond (Res-032-21/22)
title: Investing and Strengthening Social Emotional Learning Competencies and Practices Across Los Angeles Unified for College, Career and Beyond (Res-032-21/22)
Agenda_item_fulltext: Whereas, Social Emotional Learning (SEL) is the process through which young people and adults acquire and apply the knowledge, skills, and attitudes to develop healthy identities, manage emotions and achieve personal and collective goals, feel and show empathy for others, establish and maintain supportive relationships, and make responsible and caring decisions; Whereas, SEL has been shown to strengthen academic outcomes (Durak et al., 2011), improve students’ well-being (Taylor et al., 2017), and increase post-secondary success (Jones, Greenburg, & Crowley, 2015); Whereas, Recognizing the importance of addressing the needs of the whole child, the Governing Board of the Los Angeles Unified School District established SEL as one of its priority areas, as outlined in its 2021 Board Goals; andWhereas, The Board Goal stated, “The percentage of students in transitional years (Kindergarten, 5th, 6th, 8th, 10th, and 12th grade) demonstrating mastery in the social emotional competency areas of growth mindset, self-efficacy, self- management and social awareness as demonstrated by a portfolio rubric will increase from the June 2022 baseline by 50% by June 2026”; now, therefore be itResolved, That the Governing Board of the Los Angeles Unified School District hereby recognizes SEL as an integral part of education, allowing students to thrive both academically and personally, and as essential competencies for college, career and lifelong success; Resolved further, That the Board hereby directs the Superintendent to supplement the District’s Strategic Plan with a SEL Roadmap, inclusive of milestones and metrics to evaluate progress towards the adoption and implementation of Districtwide SEL competencies and standards, which includes:·	A Districtwide strategy for the adoption and integration of SEL competencies for all students, which may include: o	A process and timeline for the selection and development of district SEL standards, rooted in the Collaborative for Academic, Social, and Emotional Learning (CASEL) framework and five competencies, that are comprehensive, developmentally appropriate, culturally relevant, and vertically alignedo	A resource and program inventory of all practices and policies that affect students’ experience in schools, including a multi-tiered continuum of academic and positive behavioral instruction and support that the District offers and the opportunities to embed SEL practices and competencies ·	Supports for teachers, administrators, and staff in their teaching and implementation of the SEL standards, which may include: o	Robust, universal professional development for all certificated school-based staff in the SEL competencies and the corresponding learning standards as part of the regular District-required professional development offerings, including the New Teachers’ Institute that focuses on teaching practices and strategies that are developmentally appropriate, culturally responsive and can be incorporated into other content areas o	Updating all curriculum maps and learning targets for core subjects with the integrated Districtwide SEL competencies by the 2023-24 school yearo	The incorporation of the SEL competencies and standards into the Teaching and Learning framework, as appropriate, by the 2024-25 school yearo	The development of an SEL micro-credential offering and curriculum for educatorso	Opportunities for classified staff members to engage in learning opportunities to support the socio-emotional development of students·	Supports for students in their learning and development of SEL competencies, which may include:o	Prioritizing student voice as part of the development of the District’s roadmap, including ways to elevate their ideas, as well as refine programs and practices to reflect the student experienceo	The development of peer mentoring programs for secondary students where students can foster and cultivate the five core competencies of SEL and overall health and wellness. ·	Supports for Parents, Families, and Caregivers, which may include: o	Of the annual required Parent Center workshop offerings, at least one workshop for families focused on supporting SEL at home, including providing resources that can help support families with the Districtwide SEL competencies and standards; and, be it finally Resolved, That the District shall revise the School Experience Survey questions to align towards Districtwide SEL competencies and help improve the monitoring of the District’s SEL standards, to be adopted by the upcoming 2023-24 school year.
cosponsors: Scott Schmerelson; Jackie Goldberg; Tanya Ortiz Franklin

matter_title: Celebrating Los Angeles Unified School District’s Classified Employees’ Service, Skill and Long-Standing Commitment to Our Communities
title: Celebrating Los Angeles Unified School District’s Classified Employees’ Service, Skill and Long-Standing Commitment to Our Communities
Agenda_item_fulltext: Whereas, The Los Angeles Unified School District recognizes the over 32,000 classified employees who are dedicated in their service to public education and a vital part of the District;Whereas, Classified employees play a key role in supporting students’ academic success by assisting over 400,000 students inside and outside of the classroom in grades ETK-12, more than 22,000 students in Early Education programs and, more than 20,000 students accomplishing their career goals in Adult and Career Education Centers;Whereas, Classified employees are essential to the District’s operations providing daily service to the students, faculty, staff and families through their hard work as school employees, including clerical and technical employees, as well as bus drivers, instructional aides, library aides, paraeducators, special education assistants, library and media assistants, food service providers, security officers, computer services maintenance workers and others; Whereas, Labor partners including Service Employees International Union (SEIU) Local 99, Teamsters Local 572, California School Employee Association (CSEA) Chapter 500, Los Angeles/Orange Counties Building and Construction Trades Council, Associated Administrators of Los Angeles (AALA), Los Angeles School Police Association (LASPA) and the Los Angeles School Police Management Association (LASPMA) represent classified employees who work tirelessly to serve students and ensure a supportive, clean, safe and comfortable learning environment for both the students and faculty of the District;Whereas, During the regular academic year classified employees in the District safely transport approximately 41,000 students to and from school each day by bus; serve over 720,000 meals to students each day (including 400,000 breakfasts, 350,000 lunches, and 80,000 supper and snack meals per day); create and sustain a learning environment with clean and operational facilities and classrooms, and maintain an inviting landscape at more than 1,000 District schools and other facilities that students, parents, and the community can be proud of;Whereas, Classified employees were an integral part of the District’s landmark response to the COVID-19 pandemic and its impact on the families the District proudly serves. Since the start of the pandemic, Classified Employees served over 132 million meals at our Grab-and-Go Centers, routinely clean and sanitize schools and offices allowing for the adherence to essential safety protocols, distributed hundreds of thousands of devices and hotspots to students and families for distance learning, supported the administration of over 14.7 million COVID-19 tests and the distribution of over 120,000 vaccines as of March 2022;Whereas, In 1986, the California State Legislature decreed the third full week of May each year as Classified School Employee Week in official recognition of classified school employees, by passage of Senate Bill 1552 (Campbell); now, therefore be itResolved, That the Governing Board of the Los Angeles Unified School District hereby declares the week of May 15 – 21, 2022 as Classified School Employee Week in the District and encourages the celebration of classified school employees at our schools and throughout the District for their hard work and unwavering dedication to our students, families, and schools and the invaluable contributions they make to our educational community; and, be it finallyResolved, That the Board hereby recognizes and greatly appreciates the contributions and dedicated service of classified professionals to quality education in the District and the State of California.
cosponsors: Monica Garcia; Jackie Goldberg; George McKenna III; Nick Melvoin; Tanya Ortiz Franklin; Scott Schmerelson

matter_title: Arts Justice: Access and Equity Across the Disciplines and the District
title: Arts Justice: Access and Equity Across the Disciplines and the District
Agenda_item_fulltext: Whereas, On June 22, 2021 the Governing Board of the Los Angeles Unified School District adopted four Board Goals committing the Los Angeles Unified School District to improve student achievement in post-secondary preparation, literacy, numeracy, and social-emotional wellness; Whereas, Participating in arts education promotes creativity, wellness, healing and socio-emotional learning, which are foundational skills to achieving the Board goals; Whereas, California Education Code sections 51210 and 51220 provide that California schools must provide a course of study for students in grades 1 through 12 with courses or instruction in visual and performing arts, including dance, music, theater, and visual arts, aimed at the development of aesthetic appreciation and the skills of creative expression; Whereas, The State of California recognizes the arts as an integral part of a quality education by requiring the completion of a visual and performing arts (VAPA) course for students wishing to pursue higher education in California’s four-year public colleges; Whereas, Education Code 49011 requires that no pupil enrolled in a public school shall be required to pay to participate in an educational activity and students have the right to access all educational materials for extracurriculars or classes including but not limited to instruments, arts supplies or dance/cheer uniforms; Whereas, The California Arts Content Standards for Public Schools, Prekindergarten through Grade 12: Dance, Media Arts, Music, Theatre, Visual Arts, was adopted by the State Board of Education on January 9, 2019, to foster students’ artistic competencies; cultivate their appreciation and understanding of the arts in ways that are enjoyable, fulfilling, and transferable to personal, academic, and professional endeavors; and support them to fully engage in lifelong arts learning;Whereas, The California Arts Education Framework for Public Schools, Transitional Kindergarten Through Grade Twelve (Arts Framework) was adopted by the State Board of Education on July 8, 2020 to provide guidance for educational programs on how to implement standards based arts education. Whereas, Since 1980 the Board has adopted over 10 Board Resolutions committed to strengthening arts access and programming at the local and state levels, including in a 2012 resolution entitled, “Supporting Educational Equity, Student Achievement and Mastery of 21st Century Skills through Arts at the Core” affirming the arts as a part of core academic instruction, including direct and integrated instruction; Whereas, In 2013, the Board passed a resolution entitled, “Arts at the Core: Implementing the Arts Education and Creative Network Plan,” which called on the Superintendent to develop a plan to distribute and support the use of state and federal guidelines to administrators and school site stakeholders, integrate comprehensive arts education and arts teaching and learning, collect and disseminate data to ensure accurate and transparent information regarding equitable access to arts education, and develop budget ideas to significantly increase funding for arts education; Whereas, In 2015, the Arts Education Branch created the Arts Equity Index to assess arts programming across all schools and to help inform how K-12 arts personnel and resources are administered; Whereas, The County of Los Angeles Board of Supervisors adopted the new Los Angeles County Regional Blueprint for Arts Education on October 13, 2020, which sets forth a vision, policy, and guide for increasing equity and access in arts education for all young people across Los Angeles County, prioritizing those who have been historically excluded from learning in the arts, both in schools and in communities; Whereas, Research documents the benefits of an arts education including developed critical thinking, problem-solving, imagination, creativity, alternative ways to communicate ideas, self-esteem, empathy, academic and personal success, and students from low-income backgrounds with high access to arts in school are more likely to graduate, more likely to finish college, and register to vote than students without access to arts; Whereas, The COVID-19 pandemic significantly impacted our school communities and students’ mental health and the arts have the potential to heal trauma and decrease stress and anxiety; Whereas, An equitable Path to Recovery requires providing additional resources to our high and highest need schools including ensuring that students have access to comprehensive and rigorous coursework including arts education, now, therefore be itResolved, That the Governing Board of the Los Angeles Unified School District, as part of a comprehensive approach to achieve the Board Goals, to achieve the goals of the California State Arts Content Standards, and to meet the requirements set forth in California Education Codes 51210 and 51220, commits to equitable access to high quality, standards-based, comprehensive, sequential,culturally relevant and developmentally appropriate arts education across disciplines to all PK-12 students regardless of race, ethnicity, country of origin, family income, neighborhood of residence, gender, gender identity, disability, sexual orientation, and any other axis of historical oppression; Resolved further, That the Superintendent will analyze and respond to gaps in access to arts programming, reporting back to the Board and public within 120 days and annually with information such as: 1. What percentage of students meaningfully participate in each of the five arts disciplines (visual arts, music, dance, theater, and media arts), at least once during the instructional day disaggregated by grade level (including early education, elementary, middle and high school), and by race/ethnicity, disability, and/or language? 2. What percentage of students are in which types of programs (e.g. elective course, 9-week program, semester-long, year-long, after school extracurricular program, magnet school, in-school partnership with an external organization, or no program)? 3. How are these arts disciplines and programs funded and made available to schools (e.g. central allocation, Community of Schools (COSA) funded, school site funded, parent organization or booster club funded, community organization donation, and funding from the Arts Equity Index)? 4. How is the Arts Equity Index currently used to guide equitable investments in Arts Education? (e.g. which schools get additional funding, how much funding is allocated through the index annually etc.) 5. What are the gaps in arts education enrollment, including student-teacher ratios and arts partnerships, across SENI quintiles, Local District, Community of School, Board District, race/ethnicity, disability and/or language? How and when will these gaps be closed? 6. How equitable is access to arts facilities and equipment across schools and programs (e.g. design, renovation, construction)? What do programs have and/or need to achieve equity? 7. Potential additions or revisions to the school experience survey or other open data-collection sources to regularly review and respond to access and equity in arts education; and, be it finally Resolved, That the Los Angeles Unified School District will intentionally build and strengthen the quality and quantity of arts education, through collaborative efforts that may include: 1.	Planning to fill the gaps in current arts programming so that every student PK- 12 has an equitable opportunity to access and experience robust, comprehensive, and sequential standards-based arts instruction and courses in each of the arts disciplines during the instructional day at every grade level by ensuring a baseline of core instructional services of arts education;2.	Creating Community of Schools arts pathways to create a sequential and cohesive arts curriculum across grade levels; 3. 	Providing additional arts opportunities through supplemental school-site partnerships with arts education organizations and institutions, making publicly available a database of partners (including what services they provide, in which arts discipline(s) and which schools they partner with); 4.	Ensuring a PK-12 curriculum and pedagogy that is culturally responsive, trauma- and resiliency- informed, and inclusive for all students across identities, skills, disabilities and learning differences; and 5. 	Establishing an arts advisory council, composed of at least seven students enrolled in 6-12th grades across all Board Districts, credentialed educators across all five arts disciplines and grade spans, and relevant arts-focused partners, to analyze data gathered, inform decision making, and provide an annual update to the Board on Arts Justice progress based on qualitative and quantitative student data.
cosponsors: Nick Melvoin; Monica Garcia; Jackie Goldberg; Scott Schmerelson; Kelly Gonez

matter_title: Restructure Deaf and Hard of Hearing Education: Elevate Language Equity, Eliminate Bias in Deaf Education, and Improve Educational Outcomes
title: Restructure Deaf and Hard of Hearing Education: Elevate Language Equity, Eliminate Bias in Deaf Education, and Improve Educational Outcomes
Agenda_item_fulltext: Whereas, The Los Angeles Unified School District serves over 2,100 Deaf and Hard of Hearing students in the entire District with differing hearing levels; Whereas, Deaf and Hard of Hearing is an inclusive term to encompass identities that may change over time and place including Deaf, Hard of Hearing, DeafBlind, DeafDisabled, DeafPlus and Late-Deafened; Whereas, Current assessments should be periodically reviewed for accessibility, consistency, and performance results across Deaf and Hard of Hearing education programs; Whereas, The District is committed to using culturally/linguistically responsive programs utilizing its diverse communities, making sure that representation of said communities have a seat at the table and that racist and unconscious bias does not exist in District programs; Whereas, Consistent with the Superintendent’s 100-Day Plan to implement demand-driven actions and demand-driven steps that engage and acknowledge the many voices who have a vested interest in the success of the District, these suggestions need to be solicited from various stakeholders including oral and signing Deaf or Hard of Hearing professionals in Deaf and Hard of Hearing Education, and Deaf and Hard of Hearing community organizations who work closely with the District, as well as educators of the Deaf and Hard of Hearing and others who work in the District; andWhereas, There is law that supports the Deaf Child’s Bill of Rights (Assembly Bill 1836, codified as Education Code section 56000.5) and the position of the California Department of Education CDE on supporting the right of Deaf and Hard-of-Hearing children to full access to language from birth; now, therefore be it Resolved, That the Los Angeles Unified School District shall ensure alignment of its instructional service system with the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (IDEA) Section 300.324(a)(2)(iv) for considering these special factors: the communication needs of the child, and in the case of a child who is Deaf or Hard of Hearing, consider the child’s language and communication needs, opportunities for direct communications with peers and professional personnel in the child’s language and communication mode, academic level, and full range of needs, including opportunities for direct instruction in the child’s language and communication mode; and also align with current legislation that supports the Deaf Child’s Bill of Rights and the position of the (CDE) on supporting the right of Deaf children to full access to language from birth;Resolved further, That the Board directs the Superintendent to evaluate its efforts to support children who are Deaf and Hard of Hearing within the Special Education Department including potential establishment of a Deaf and Hard of Hearing Education Department that is separate from the Low Incidence Department and oversees a variety of programs that involve Deaf and Hard of Hearing children, Deaf and Hard of Hearing education professionals, and families with Deaf and Hard of Hearing children or other structural changes to enhance the level of expertise and dedicated support for families with Deaf or Hard of Hearing children and Deaf and Hard of Hearing Education professionals;Resolved further, That the Division of Special Education shall report back to the Governing Board of the Los Angeles Unified School District in 45 days if it does not think such a department is necessary, and provide information considered in making this determination;Resolved further, That an Advisory Committee of Deaf and Hard of Hearing (including BIPOC) education professionals shall be established to collaborate with Human Resources to provide input into and to help develop processes for the recruitment, hiring, training and retention of qualified Deaf and Hard of Hearing education professionals;Resolved further, That all families of Deaf and Hard of Hearing babies (age 0-3) be given complete, accurate, and unbiased information regarding all language and program options.Resolved further, That the District’s Deaf and Hard of Hearing Education Infant program will be adapted to encompass an evidence-based bilingual approach of American Sign Language (ASL) and English with unbiased curricula, and that all Deaf babies (age 0-3) will begin the infant program in a bimodal ASL-English Bilingual (AEB) program subject to parental consent through the (IDEA), Sec. 300.324(a)(2)(iv), Individualized Family Service Plan (IFSP) process with:a)	Concurrent and accessible parent education classes b)	Recognition and placement decisions are made by, Individualized Family Service Plan (IFSP) teams, which includes the parents and others, consistent with IDEA Section 300.344 and Part B Regulations participants, which may include an administrator, program specialist or teacher, and accurately interpreted to address the academic, linguistic, social and emotional development of Deaf students per IDEA Section 300.324(a)(2)(i)-(v) and (Education Code 56345[e]) c)	Ensure Hard of Hearing, Deafness, Multiple Disabilities-Hearing are listed as the primary eligibility for appropriate placements to foster linguistic needs of Deaf students per Senate Bill 210 Language Equality & Acquisition for Deaf Kids (LEAD-K); Resolved further, That the Board directs the Superintendent to expand the number of courses in secondary schools for ASL as a world language option with a particular emphasis in the provision of such courses for Deaf and Hard of Hearing students, as well as offering ASL classes as an opportunity for parents;Resolved, That the District formally recognizes ASL as a language of instruction for Deaf and Hard of Hearing students to:a)	Acknowledge ASL/English Bilingual programs in the District with the goal of fluency in ASL and English and recognized by CDE’s seal of biliteracy currently awarded at California State Schools for the Deaf b)	Adopt the National ASL Content Standardsc)	Explore the value of including ASL/English Bilingual Deaf Education programs under Bilingual Education and Multilingual and Multicultural Education Departments and being recognized within those departments on the District website d)	Develop AEB resources to support language acquisitione)	Implement ASL/English immersion program for prelingual, semilingual and newcomer Deaf and Hard of Hearing students with qualified bilingual specialistsf)	Explore possible methods of providing ASL classes for Deaf and Hard of Hearing students at the high school level to develop their language, be inclusive of their identity and fulfill A-G requirements and college entry requirements and, be it finallyResolved, That nothing in this resolution shall prevent any parent or guardian from exercising all of their rights at an IEP.
cosponsors: Scott Schmerelson; George McKenna III; Tanya Ortiz Franklin

matter_title: Remembering and Honoring the Significance of the Armenian Genocide of 1915 (Res-024-21/22)
title: Remembering and Honoring the Significance of the Armenian Genocide of 1915 (Res-024-21/22)
Agenda_item_fulltext: Whereas, This year, Armenian Genocide Remembrance Day will be recognized April 24, 2022, marking the 107th anniversary of the Armenian Genocide;Whereas, The Armenian people were subjects of a systematic and premeditated genocidal campaign, which began at the hands of the Ottoman government, through 1919 and continued under the Kemalist government of the Republic of Turkey from 1920 through 1923, whereby 1.5 million Armenian men, women and children were slaughtered or marched to their deaths in an effort to annihilate the Armenian Nation in the first modern genocide, while thousands of kidnapped children and young women were forced to change their Armenian names to Turkish names and convert to Islam, and hundreds of thousands more were subjected to ethnic cleansing during the period of the modern Republic of Turkey from 1924 through 1937;Whereas, These crimes against humanity also had the consequence of permanently removing all traces of the Armenians and other targeted people from their historic homelands, and enriching the perpetrators with the lands and other property of the victims of these crimes, including the usurpation of several thousand churches; Whereas, In response to the Genocide, the Near East Relief organization, the first Congressionally sanctioned American philanthropic effort created exclusively to rescue the Armenian Nation and other Christian minorities, was founded and provided unprecedented relief, delivering more than $117 million of humanitarian assistance between 1915 and 1930, and saving approximately one million refugees, including 130,000 orphans of the Genocide;Whereas, The Republic of Turkey has inexplicably and adamantly denied the occurrence of the crimes against humanity committed by the Ottoman and Young Turk rulers for many years, and continues to do so a full century since the first crimes constituting genocide occurred, despite the Turkish government’s earlier admissions and the overwhelming proof of genocidal intent;Whereas, The State of California has been at the forefront of encouraging and promoting a curriculum relating to human rights and genocide in order to empower future generations to prevent recurrence of genocide;Whereas, The Governor of California, in accordance with Assembly Concurrent Resolution 51, proclaimed April 24 of each year as a State Day of Remembrance in recognition of the anniversary of the Armenian Genocide;Whereas, The concern for human rights is a major element in the History-Social Science framework for California public schools, Kindergarten through 12th grade;Whereas, The Los Angeles Unified School District has been at the forefront of mandating that the Armenian Genocide not only be taught, but discussed and made a focal teaching point for universal religious and ethnic tolerance;Whereas, the District is committed to confronting difficult subjects, including the Armenian Genocide, in inclusive ways that ensure all students are respected and has strong nondiscrimination and anti-bullying policies to that end;  Whereas, Despite the significance of the Armenian Genocide both to the country and people of Armenia and to the history of the 20th century, teaching the history of the genocide with fidelity and cultural sensitivity often requires our educators to go deeper than our existing curricula provides;Whereas, On April 23, 2019, the Governing Board of the Los Angeles Unified School District adopted Remembering and Honoring the Armenian Genocide of 1915 (Res-036-18/19), which sought to explore ways to recognize Armenian Genocide Remembrance Day and, as appropriate, other diverse cultural holidays recognized by our families, in school calendars set to go into effect in the 2021-2022 school year; Whereas, On October 16, 2020, the Board unanimously passed “Honoring the Significance of April 24th in the Los Angeles Unified School District” (Res-008-20/21), designating April 24th as an unassigned day on District school calendars beginning in the 2022-2023 school year to honor the Armenian Genocide, keep the school calendar consistent across the District, and address transportation, attendance, and staff challenges; Whereas, The District has a significant Armenian student population, many of whom have family members who experienced first-hand the horror and evil of the Armenian Genocide and the ongoing denial of the Armenian Genocide; now, therefore be it Resolved, That the Governing Board of the Los Angeles Unified School District hereby commemorates April as the month of “Commemoration of the Anniversary of the Armenian Genocide of 1915” and April 24th as “Armenian Genocide Remembrance Day”; and, be it finallyResolved, That in doing so, the Board directs the Superintendent to seek to expand professional development opportunities to ensure that the Armenian Genocide is appropriately and meaningfully taught to students, staff, and the community at large, using inclusive, accessible materials that promote understanding and tolerance across cultures.
cosponsors: Scott Schmerelson; Nick Melvoin; Jackie Goldberg; Parishi Kanuga

matter_title: Appointment of Member to the School Construction Bond Citizens’ Oversight Committee (Sup Res 011-21/22)
title: Appointment of Member to the School Construction Bond Citizens’ Oversight Committee (Sup Res 011-21/22)
Agenda_item_fulltext: Resolved, That the Governing Board of the Los Angeles Unified School District ratifies the appointment of Mr. Scott Pansky, representing the Los Angeles Area Chamber of Commerce, as a Member to the School Construction Bond Citizens’ Oversight Committee for a two-year term commencing immediately. Mr. Pansky is not an employee, official, vendor, contractor, or consultant of the District.
